subject: Art
title: Pairing Typefaces
description: Combining two typefaces that contrast beautifully and create hierarchy.

hook.text: One typeface for headings, another for body text. The pair should contrast clearly but harmonize visually â€” like a good duet where the voices are different but complementary.

buildup.text: Classic pairings: serif heading + sans body (or vice versa). The key: contrast in structure but harmony in proportions. Match x-heights approximately. Different enough to create hierarchy, similar enough to not clash.

discovery.text: Safe strategy: pair typefaces from the same designer or foundry â€” they often share underlying proportions. Or use superfamilies (like Merriweather + Merriweather Sans) designed to work together.

twist.text: The biggest mistake: pairing two typefaces that are too similar. Two different sans-serifs of similar weight looks like an error. The viewer thinks: 'Are these supposed to be the same?' Contrast or match â€” never almost-match.

climax.text: Try: Playfair Display (high-contrast serif) + Source Sans Pro (clean sans). The dramatic serif heading contrasts clearly with the neutral sans body. Hierarchy is instant and the pairing feels natural.

punchline.text: Two typefaces maximum. Contrast clearly. When in doubt, use one typeface family in different weights.

quiz.question: What is the biggest mistake when pairing typefaces?
options: Pairing two typefaces that are too similar â€” creating ambiguity rather than contrast
